title: Ni (Dominant) confirmation
intro: Answer based on your long-term patterns. Choose 4–5 only if it is consistently true across your life. If you choose 4–5, you can optionally tick grounded examples (not required).

items.text: I feel best when my life has a clear direction or purpose; without it I feel uneasy or adrift.
examples: If I don’t know what I’m aiming toward, my motivation drops sharply.
I naturally look for a ‘north star’ before I commit time/effort.
Having a meaningful goal matters more to me than small daily comforts.
When my future feels unclear, I become anxious or overly serious.
I often ask myself ‘where is this going?’ about school/work/relationships.

items.text: I naturally synthesize information into a single underlying idea, theme, or implication.
examples: I prefer one unifying explanation over many separate facts.
I quickly form a ‘big picture’ and then evaluate details through it.
I often notice what something ‘really means’ or where it is heading.
I dislike discussions that stay purely on surface details.
I often reduce a mess of information into a simple principle.

items.text: I often have strong intuitive impressions about how things will play out, even before I can explain why.
examples: I get a clear ‘this will probably happen’ sense from subtle cues.
I can’t always explain my reasoning, but my forecast often proves correct.
I trust pattern-recognition more than step-by-step checking in many cases.
I feel uncomfortable when forced to act without a guiding insight.
I notice trajectory (where things are heading) more than the current snapshot.

items.text: I’m drawn to an ideal vision and I can delay gratification to pursue it; I can become perfectionistic about it.
examples: I’d rather sacrifice short-term comfort for long-term progress.
I feel dissatisfied when results fall below my internal standard.
I can become controlling about quality because the ideal matters.
I get frustrated when people ‘settle’ too easily.
I track symbolic signs of progress (milestones, levels, status markers).

items.text: When I’m low, I judge things as shallow/meaningless and I suffer when my future looks bleak or uncertain.
examples: I become cynical when I can’t see meaning or direction.
A vague future makes me feel heavy or trapped.
I can become intense or withdrawn when my vision breaks.
I struggle to enjoy the present if the long-term path feels wrong.
I feel better once I re-establish a coherent ‘why’.

items.text: I often dislike people who feel shallow, short-sighted, narrow-minded, or unable to think ahead.
examples: I get irritated by ‘living only for today’ with no larger aim.
I dislike reckless behavior that ignores future consequences.
I feel limited around people who can’t discuss deeper implications.
I dislike fickleness or constant switching with no direction.
I’m frustrated by conversations that never connect to meaning.

items.text: I rarely think about purpose or where my life is going; I’m fine living mostly in the moment.
examples: I don’t care much about ‘calling’ or a big direction.
I feel okay without a long-range plan.
I mostly focus on immediate tasks and enjoyment.
Long-term vision talk feels unnecessary or boring.
I don’t feel anxious about an uncertain future.

items.text: I prefer literal, concrete talk and everyday details; symbolism/meaning talk feels vague or pointless.
examples: I’d rather discuss practical steps than abstract themes.
I don’t enjoy interpreting deeper meaning in events or stories.
I prefer ‘what happened’ over ‘what it represents’.
I find philosophy-like discussion tiring.
I value clear facts more than interpretation.

items.text: I don’t need a single guiding framework; I’m happy to keep options open and change direction often.
examples: I dislike committing to one long-term vision.
I prefer flexibility over focus.
I switch interests easily without needing a central theme.
I don’t feel stress from ‘unfinished direction’.
I feel trapped by long-horizon commitments.

items.text: People rarely describe me as intense, vague, unrealistic, or hard to read; I’m usually straightforward and concrete.
examples: I’m usually seen as practical and present-focused.
I don’t get called ‘mysterious’ or ‘too serious’.
My thinking is easy for others to follow step-by-step.
I rarely get stuck in abstract future scenarios.
I rarely overthink meaning or implications.
